28.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain, coming up:
The legendary Crow is after Roe and a bag

34.text:
full of pigeons. We've got News Stump, we've
got Hallo Charlie, we've got Hunting Youtube.

39.text: First I'm on a mission to make Rook Pie.

56.text:
The branchers that can nearly but not quite
fly head out of the nest in mid May and should

62.text:
make easy targets for airguns. That's why
son Edmund and I take the airgun to the wood

68.text: to try to shoot a couple for the pot.

74.text:
Going back 700 years and rook was a popular
dish. Medieval kitchens cooked all sorts of

79.text:
stuff unusual by our standards [use unicorn
shot] and the tradition was to send small

83.text:
boys up trees to grab branchers, which they
say is as good as pigeon but unfairly discriminated

89.text:
against because of their colour. But times
have changed, and instead of boys we have

94.text:
boys toys. Darren took these shots of the
young bird in their nest using his quadcopter.

104.text:
Going back seven years and if you want an
example of why the country is going to hell

108.text:
in a dog basket, why there are indeed blackbirds
over the greyish cliffs of Dover, Gordon Ramsay

114.text:
was investigated for shooting branchers for
the pot. Technically, you can only shoot rooks

120.text:
if they are an agricultural menace. Now I
know what you are thinking: surely we could

125.text: have got Ramsay on something by now.

127.text:
Happily for Edmund and me, there are no blue
flashing light, the ARU remains in the helipad

132.text:
coffee lounge and the lad stays out of the
young offenders institute for a few more days.

138.text:
What saves the rooks is their name, 'branchers'.
There is such a tangle of ash and beech branches

143.text:
in this wood, we can't get an airgun pellet
near them. So the dogs get back in the car

148.text:
and we head home for a rethink. And that rethink
has me replacing Ed with the new Fieldsports

153.text:
Channel intern, Tom, and replacing the airgun
with shotguns.

164.text:
Of course the problem with using a shotgun
is that one bang and the birds lift into the

168.text:
air. All the branchers that up to now had
been too nervous to take off suddenly find

174.text:
We wait and we wait for the birds to come
back into range. The heifers take a keen interest.

179.text: Not sure I can do this with an audience.

181.text:
Eventually the dogs take matters into their
own hands. They find an unlucky young rook

185.text:
on the ground and peg it.
Now, shooting rooks on low branches with shotguns,

190.text:
or even grabbing them off the floor, is easy
sport for the month of May. I am going somewhere

195.text:
with this. I have got a few scraps of game
in the freezer I want to clear out and I need

199.text:
a few more to make a game pie. Earlier that
morning, I go out with my dad to his wood

205.text:
As we walk in towards the wood, two roebuck
race out of it, passing us at 20 feet, then

212.text:
one chases the other over the road and returns.
It is limping. As it comes down the fenceline

217.text:
I move into position. I shoot it at 25 yards
and it goes straight down.

238.text:
There you are , Roebuck are easy. Now back
to the slightly trickier question of Branchers.

249.text:
Now for the cookery. Don't get excited. This
is Gordon Ramsay's rook salad, which he does

256.text:
with the benefit of the finest ingredients
and a Channel 4 TV budget.

262.text:
We don't have Gordon. We have Tom, who is
joining us for two months on a work placement

266.text:
from the Royal Agricultural College at Cirencester
where he is studying food. He is a qualified

272.text:
chef. He is also a student. How does the modern
student cook rook?

276.text:
It will probably taste distinctly average,
I think, is the best way to describe it!

302.text:
Well you will have to take my word for it,
it was delicious.And something else that some

306.text:
people will find delicious, no that's wrong,
David, on the Fieldsports Channel News Stump!

318.text:
This is Fieldsports Channel News
Six people have been arrested after wild boars

324.text:
were released during a burglary at a farm
in Wales. Farmer Greg Davis, of Llangynwyd,

329.text:
near Maesteg, says more than 40 of the animals
could be roaming the area after they were

333.text:
released from their pen following a break-in
at. The British wild boar population is thriving.

339.text:
Viewer David Smith sent in these pictures
of wild boar tip toeing through the bluebells

344.text: on Exmoor in the West of England.

347.text:
Staying on Exmoor and a deerstalker has shot
an unusual malform. Viewer Stuart Parish of

353.text:
Exmoor sent in these pictures of a strange-looking
roe buck. One antler has grown normally, but

358.text:
the other has grown down the side of its head.
It's time to spread the love and introduce

363.text:
someone to shooting in the UK.National Shooting
Week takes place from 24th-31st May. Organised

370.text:
by the Countryside Alliance, it includes reduced
rates at claygrounds all over the country.

380.text:
Lawmakers in Louisiana have declared fox pen
hunting part of the American state's folklife

386.text:
heritage. The sport involves training hunting
dogs to pursue foxes in fenced-in preserves.

392.text:
The foxes are chased up trees and are seldom
killed.

396.text:
Norway is on course to repeal its ban on lead
shot. The main political party in Norway plans

402.text:
to lift the ban on lead on shot, outside wetlands
and clay shooting grounds. The Norway Hunters'

407.text:
Association successfully argued that the amount
of lead discharged throughout the countryside

412.text:
has a negligible impact on the environment.
Meanwhile, Denmark plans to ban tungsten shot

419.text:
Global warming may hit roe deer populations
across Europe. Almost extinct in parts of

424.text:
Europe in the late 17th century, the roe deer
bounced back and today is one of the most

428.text:
widespread deer on the continent. However,
it is not adapting to climate change. In Champagne

434.text:
in eastern France, hotter temperatures over
the past few decades have resulted in earlier

438.text:
springs. But the timing of roe deer births
has remained unchanged, according to a team

443.text:
of scientists from France and UK, so fewer
roe kids are surviving.

448.text:
Locals in Newquay, Cornwall, have found themselves
battling an infestation of 'massive' rodents,

455.text:
and are worried the super-sized vermin are
becoming increasingly bold. Residents say

459.text:
that a new housing development may have disturbed
the vermin who are now prowling the resort

464.text:
and terrorizing people. The rat population
has boomed since the council stopped providing

472.text:
Got a problem bear in your backyard? The State
Government of Wisconsin is holding "Learn

478.text:
to Bear Hunt" courses throughout the state
in the upcoming months. You have to be over

482.text:
ten years old and you will learn how to read
bear sign, check bear baits, handle hound

488.text:
dogs, you will practise safe firearm handling
and receive target shooting tips. Apply at

496.text:
And finally a motorist in Finland stopped
his car to film this woodcock on the road.

501.text:
He was playing music in the car and it appears
to be dancing. Thanks to viewer Nick Warren

510.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsport Channel
News, stalking for stories, fishing for facts.

518.text:
Thank you David. Now lets see what you lot
have been up to. It is Hallo Charlie!

527.text:
Hallo Charlie, it's Paul up in Scotland. It's
a cold, wet one. But we're doing some deer

541.text:
Hello Charlie, I'm Paul, I'm Luke and we're
both aged 15 and we've bought the airarm .400

548.text:
and I've just shot two rabbits with one shot.
Two lovely little rabbits.

552.text:
Hello Charlie, this is Phil here, out stalking
a few rabbits tonight Any corvets that should

558.text:
come their way as well. Any way, good night
from sunny Dorset.

563.text:
Hello Charlie. Paul, Callum, George doing
a bit of ferrel pigeon control in the local

570.text:
dairy farm for the farmer using the NS200.
Cracking bit of kit. Bye Charlie, bye Charlie,

579.text:
Hello Charlie, Paul from Hampshire here. Lovely
sunny evening. Just out for a walk with my

587.text:
new rifle. It's been a good night. Keep up
the good work.

591.text:
Hello Charlie, it's Adam from Manchester.
I've just taken my friend Danny out on his

599.text:
Hello Charlie, Richard here in the Chilterns
in Hertfordshire. 5000 acres of National Trust.

606.text:
Vermin shooting, which I hardly ever get out
on. There's not terribly much about today.

609.text:
It's Hammy here, having a nice rough shoot
out here in Norfolk. Been a bit of a quiet

615.text:
Send us your own Hallo Charlie. Film yourself
on your mobile phone, just a sentence saying

618.text:
Hallo Charlie, who you are and what you're
up to and then share it or email it via youtube,

623.text:
facebook, dropbox or you send it you name
it to Charlie at fieldsportschannel.tv.

628.text:
And please keep sending those videos in. Next
up, Crow's out after pigeons.

648.text:
These days Captain Crow is resorting to aerial
surveillance to find his pigeons .And it's

653.text:
working. There are hundreds of birds up here
in north Kent but they're not all wood pigeons

656.text:
and today is going to be as much about species
identification as it is shooting.

661.text:
Stock doves have got a lot faster wing beat,
wood pigeons have got a slower wing beat.

666.text:
Crow doesn't want to waste his Gamebore shells
on ferals, and the stock doves, are protected.

673.text:
Now he's parked his chopper, let's start with
why this is the place for us today.

678.text:
We used growing maze last year for the cover
crop and it's just yellow so what they are

684.text:
doing is just feeding on the peas all day
and coming in here just for a last feed to

687.text:
get a bit of protein out of the maze. We thought
we'd get here now it's half three, get set

692.text: up for a few hours and see how we get on.

694.text:
It's looking quite promising, the wind is
in our backs, or in our sides really. So everything

704.text:
is going to come up from the wood, come up
through. Got a big Ash Tree here which they

708.text:
make for. I've had a lot of good days here,
so I know they will make for these Ash Trees

711.text:
so if I can shoot 15/20 pigeons I will be
happy. I haven't been shooting the gun much

713.text:
this year so it will be nice just to, well
it just is nice to get out and have a few

720.text:
So it's a combination of flight lines, wind,
food and timing. If you don't know when they're

726.text:
filling their crops with your crops, you will
waste a lot of time looking at 'Sky' -- and

732.text:
Crow has defrosted a few real birds for the
pattern, as well as his decoys. His whirly

736.text:
is either being held together by tape or there's
some crow-sense behind it.

737.text:
I've got a long hazel stick, goes in its back
passage, goes right the way through out of

743.text:
the front of the rib cage, right up its neck
into its head. Stick it in the ground. Break

755.text:
both of it's wings, like that and it blows
in the wind. It's just a bit of movement.

762.text:
I've watched a few people using whirlys and
they are like a flashing mirror going round

765.text:
and round. So, all mine, I get some tape,
well I get mine from A1 but you can get some

771.text:
from anywhere. Just a tape, camouflage tape.
I just wind it all along. It just stops it

776.text:
glinting. Because every time it goes round
there is somewhere where it catches the sun

783.text:
while mine are all taped up and it doesn't
matter what you paint it with it still shines.

789.text:
Interesting. And if you have ever wondered
what it's like to be impaled on a whirly and

792.text:
spun around -- hold on tight..................That's
quite enough of that.

825.text:
With us today is Sporting Shooter editor Dom
Holtam. He's not brought a gun, which is a

830.text:
shame, as there's so much for the pigeons
to feed on that keeping the birds focused

834.text:
in one spot might be out problem. That was
the issue on our last outing -- however, there

841.text:
are definitely more birds on the move and
they do seem to be decoying this time.

845.text:
If we keep chipping away at them like that,
we may get 50 or 60. I know we're going to

858.text:
get at least a dozen. We've got that about
now .

861.text:
Crow gets some nice shots with his Lincoln
Deluxe, which has served him well during this

865.text:
series of CrowHow. The wind direction dictates
that most of the birds are coming in from

877.text:
our right. Some stay our side of the shore
-- others drop the other side to come in from

884.text:
The ideal place would be with the wind behind
us, coming from behind and the pigeons will

892.text:
have been coming from in front, there, instead
of that one, which came from behind.

897.text:
Crow has to be quick to react to the birds
which are motoring in the wind. He throws

901.text:
the Lincoln around to get onto the birds,
while identifying if it is indeed a woodie.

906.text:
In front the identification is easy for him.
When they drop in from behind it's much tougher.

912.text:
Someone else who's in a hurry is this buck
chasing a doe. The wind is clearly up him

918.text:
There is talk about going stalking but we
think we're about to run out of luck dodging

921.text:
the rain showers. With the sky looking ominous
we start to pack up. We've been out for about

928.text:
Yes, it's been a good afternoon, but this
maze here will last them a month. They will

935.text:
be on that now until the peas start flowering.
But no, it's been a good afternoon.

945.text:
The clear-up reveals one of the biggest bags
he's had in a long time -- 80+ birds... And

951.text:
he must be happy -- as he's even treating
us to some Karaoke or should that be Karee-Crow-kee.

965.text:
From the West Country to the wider world of
hunting and shooting on Youtube, it is Hunting

974.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting and shooting videos that

978.text:
Schools Challenge champion of champions Sam
Mullins won a Bowman clay pigeon trap at the

983.text:
recent Bredon leg of the Schools Challenge.
To watch that, click on the link on the screen.

987.text:
Now he has made a film of him using his new
trap, using some of the skills that gave him

992.text:
an average 48 ex 5o at two clay events. He
has only been shooting for seven months.

997.text:
TheShootingShow gives us its take on brancher
shooting, saving a local pea field one rook

1003.text:
Next we are off to Scotland where HuntShootFish
is iScoping rabbits along walls and hedgerows.

1008.text:
Rabbit after rabbits falls over and he is
honest enough to show the ones that don't.

1012.text:
Now abroad. Hunting Stories is after deer
and boar in this film designed to plug his

1018.text:
To Turkey where Bilalarabaci is filming partridge
shooting over pointers. The dog work is good,

1024.text:
though they do run in a bit. My spaniels would
never do that, heaven forfend.

1029.text:
DownWindOutdoors has had some trouble producing
the outstanding films it likes to present

1033.text:
so its Eastern Coyote Hunting with AR-15 is
its first after a long fallow winter. This

1039.text: film shows it is back in action.

1041.text:
I'm a big fan of Bunny Hunter who is here
duck hunting in Horicon Marsh, Wisconsin.

1046.text:
This event was for the local vets of the Wounded
Warrior Project -- vets being the American

1050.text: veterans in this situation, not veterinarians

1053.text:
And finally, staying in the USA, Steve Gould
meets Annie Oakley. Trickshooter Steve tries

1057.text:
the mirror shot, using a mirror to aim a rifle
over his shoulder at a target that is behind

1061.text:
him. Annie Oakley made the shot famous. Let's
see if Steve can pull it off. And can you?

1066.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you are missing the fishing films

1069.text:
and the airgun films, watch our new shows,
AirHeads and Fishing Britain. If you have

1073.text:
a YouTube film you would like us to pop in
to the weekly top eight, send it in via YouTube

1076.text: or email me the link charlie@fieldsportschannel.tv

1081.text:
Well you saw the clever plug for Schools Challenge
there. Among our other shows we've got Fishing

1087.text:
Thank you Charlie. Today we are on Draycot
Water in the Midlands, near Rugby and we are

1093.text:
out Trout Fishing. Now one of the big questions
I get asked is what fly do I put on - do I

1099.text:
use. Here are a few pointers: Before you go
out to float, check in the harbour - Can you

1103.text:
see any insects? Turn over a few stones, see
if you can see anything. Or when you get out

1108.text:
here, have a look in the water. Have a look
to see if you can see any buzzer shucks. Now

1112.text:
the shuck is where the buzzer has hatched
and flown away but it will give you an indication

1117.text:
of what size they are. Better still, catch
a fish, then spoon it. You get a mara spoon.

1123.text:
Stick it down into its stomach rotate it a
couple of times. Now to make it easier to

1127.text:
spot what's in there put it in the bailer,
water in the bailer, wash it out. That will

1132.text:
separate all the buzzers. Now in this fish
was some small olive. Now you are not going

1137.text:
represent them, because they are too small
but there are a couple of big black ones.

1141.text:
A couple of big olives. Now that's what the
fish are feeding on. That's what you put on.

1145.text:
Then you will have a successful day. However,
having seen all those buzzers which would

1151.text:
probably be a size ten, why then am I going
to be fishing with this monster. Well, if

1156.text:
you want to find out, click on the link here
or check out Fishing Britain, every Friday

1162.text: night at 7pm, here on Fieldsports Channel.

1167.text:
Click on the link on the screen to watch Fishing
Britain and click on the link on the screen

1173.text:
There are rats in our dockyards. One of them
(the dockyards not the rats) calls up ratshooter

1178.text:
Darren Rogers to bring along his night-time
kit to sort them out - night vision, PCP,

1181.text:
you name it, he is kitted up. That's not all:
We've got gas ram action -- and it's nothing

1186.text:
to do with smelly sheep. James Marchington
compares gas ram with ordinary springer and

1190.text:
PCP. And guest stars include Dave Craze of
Ronnie Sunshines, Peter Zamit of The Airgun

1195.text:
Centre, Tony Belas of Daystate, Lord Ted of
Holdover, Sir Terence Doe and various surfs,

1201.text:
villeins and slaves including David on the
News Stump.

1204.text:
Well, we are back next week and if you are
watching this on Youtube do not hesitate to

1208.text:
hit the subscribe button somewhere on the
outside of this screen or go to our webpage,

1212.text:
fieldsportschannel.tv where you can click
to like us on facebook or follow us on twitter

1215.text:
or pop your email address into the constant
contact box and we will constantly contact

1219.text:
you about our programme which is out 7pm,
UKtime. This has been Fieldsports Britain.

1226.text:
Good hunting, good shooting, good fishing
and good bye.
